Case study: Goals

2022-10-10

Source: vignettes/art-001-case-goals.Rmd
art-001-case-goals.Rmd

Part 1 of a case study in three parts, illustrating how we work with longitudinal Student Unit Records (SUR).

  1. Goals (this page). Introducing the study.

  2. Data. Transforming the data to yield the observations of interest.

  3. Results. Calculating summary statistics and metrics and displaying the results.

Definitions

student unit records (SUR)

Registrar’s student-level data compiled by an institution and anonymized and curated by the MIDFIELD data steward. SURs include personal information (e.g., age, sex, and race/ethnicity), enrollment information (e.g., institution, program, and grade level), and academic information (e.g., courses, grades, and degrees). MIDFIELD data are organized into four tables—student, course, term, and degree—keyed by student ID.

program stickiness

The ratio \((S)\) of the number of students graduating from a program \((N_g)\) to the number of students ever enrolled in the program \((N_e)\). \[ S=\frac{N_g}{N_e} \]

Stickiness is a more-inclusive alternative to graduation rate as a measure of of a program’s success in attracting, keeping, and graduating their undergraduates. All students excluded by the conventional definition of graduation rate are included in the stickiness metric: part-time, transfers, admitted in any term, and migrators (Ohland et al., 2012).

Goals

The technical goal of the case study is to compare the program stickiness of Civil, Electrical, Industrial, and Mechanical Engineering programs with students grouped by race/ethnicity and sex.

The meta-goal of the case study is to illustrate a typical procedure for working with SUR data.

What the case study does

  • We focus on our procedures and underlying rationale for working with SURs.

  • For reproducibility, we provide all the necessary code.

  • We use the data.table package instead of base R or the dplyr package for speed, memory efficiency, and concise transforms via the []-indexing operator.

  • We use the ggplot2 package instead of base R or lattice (or other R packages) because: ggplot2’s layered approach allows plots to evolve (or devolve) with minimal changes to code; easily-invoked facets and legends simplify multivariate exploration; and its popularity yields extensive online help.

What the case study does not do

  • For brevity in the case study, we do not explain the details of midfieldr syntax, functions, or arguments. Those details are covered in other vignettes.

  • We do not explain data.table or ggplot2 syntax except for selected functions. Such details are available in numerous online resources including the data.table and ggplot2 home pages.

References

Dowle, M., & Srinivasan, A. (2021). data.table: Extension of data.frame. R package version 1.14.2. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=data.table
Ohland, M., Orr, M., Layton, R., Lord, S., & Long, R. (2012). Introducing stickiness as a versatile metric of engineering persistence. Proceedings of the Frontiers in Education Conference, 1–5.
Wickham, H. (2016). ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. ISBN 978-3-319-24277-4; Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org
